awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Artificially Intelligent Dialogic Reading Aid
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an artificial intelligence (AI)-driven tool that caregivers and early educators can use to enhance the learning impacts of reading with young children. This technology is important because one in every three children begins kindergarten insufficiently prepared to learn to read. Not only are these early reading differences associated with individual children's academic, economic, and health outcomes, but they also have implications at the national level. By some estimates, low levels of adult literacy may cost the United States $2.2 trillion annually in lost personal income, lower employment, poorer health, and weaker overall economic growth. The primary goal of this project is to develop a reading tool that can help mitigate these negative outcomes. Successful development and commercialization of the tool is expected to promote children's school readiness and early literacy, which lays at the foundation for: 1) greater academic success, 2) higher rates of high school graduation, 3) improved financial and health outcomes. and 4) substantial economic and social benefits at the national level.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an AI tool that will facilitate active conversational engagement, as opposed to passive listening, in the context of joint book reading. The technology generates story-specific prompts at opportune times during a shared reading session for adults to use as conversation starters. Users will be able to select the difficulty level and content of prompts to accommodate the skills, goals, and interests of individual readers. The technology will also be able to operate in any language, thereby maximizing potential reach. Extensive interviews will generate data from both end-users and potential distributors to guide the development and commercialization strategies for this early literacy intervention tool. These interviews will focus on three customer segments: 1) parents of young children (especially those facing socioeconomic, linguistic, or health-related challenges), 2) early education stakeholders (e.g., preschool teachers, libraries, and other literacy-focused non-profit organizations and government agencies), and 3) children's literature publishers and retailers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nearly one in three children enters kindergarten without the foundational language and literacy skills needed for success  (National Center for Educational Statistics, 2022). These early literacy gaps are linked to long-term challenges, including lower academic achievement, reduced job prospects, and poorer health outcomes.  At a national level, low literacy contributes to an estimated $2.2 trillion annual loss in economic productivity due to lower wages, higher unemployment, and increased social service costs (Rothwell, 2020). 

 

To address this challenge, our team developed the Artificially Intelligent Dialogic Reading Aide (AIDA) – a mobile application designed to help parents and early educators engage in Dialogic Reading, a research-backed approach that enhances children's language development. Research highlights the critical role of the home learning environment in fostering early literacy skills. AIDA leverages advances in AI to generate open-ended discussion prompts, enriching shared book reading experiences between adult readers and preschool-aged children. By making interactive reading more accessible, AIDA aims to support families and educators in helping ensure that all children are well prepared to begin Kindergarten. 

 

With funding from the I-Corps program, we conducted over 150 interviews with key stakeholders, including parents, preschool teachers, librarians, literacy-focused nonprofits, government agencies, and children’s book publishers. These interviews provided critical insights that shaped AIDA’s design, distribution strategy, and commercialization plan. 

 

Intellectual Merit

The sponsored work allowed us to reach several important insights: 

  1. Perhaps most importantly, we learned that marketing to organizations already working with parents to combat the literacy crisis is likely to be far more successful than trying to sell directly to parents in the already overcrowded educational technology market. These customers are already motivated to provide support for family literacy and have budgeted funds ear-marked for this purpose. 

  2. We also learned that many such organizations were interested in application features that would allow them to track student learning over time (e.g., changes in conversational turns, number of books read, vocabulary gains). 

  3. Another key discovery was that, to ensure the long-term sustainability of our technology, we would need to develop our own large language model (LLM), rather than rely on OpenAI’s 

  4. chatGPT. Building an in-house model would help keep costs low, enhance data privacy – an especially critical factor when working with children – and reduce reliance on third-party tools, giving us greater control over the technology. 

  5. Finally, we learned that partnership – either directly with children’s book publishers or with early literacy organizations that have existing contracts with publishers – will be necessary in order to ensure compliance with copyright law. 

 

Broader Impacts

The successful commercialization of AIDA has the potential to significantly improve children’s school readiness and early literacy outcomes. Based on existing data (e.g., Marchman & Fernald, 2008; US Department of Education, 2009), the broader impacts of this foundational intervention will likely include:

  1. Greater academic achievement and higher high school graduation rates.

  2. Improved long-term financial stability and health outcomes for individuals.

  3. Substantial economic benefits, including lower costs for special education and social services, as well as increased workforce productivity and tax revenue (Barber & Mourshed, 2009).

  4. Social benefits at the National level in the form of lower special education and incarceration costs (e.g., Sun et al., 2009).

Additionally, this project provided valuable interdisciplinary training for two postdoctoral researchers, equipping them with expertise in early literacy interventions, AI technology, and business development – skills that will contribute to future innovations in educational technology.

By refining our approach and fostering strategic partnerships, we have laid the groundwork for AIDA to empower families and educators to ensure the success of all children as they enter school and to lay a solid foundation for their  lifelong learning.
